title: Boris Johnson ‘strongly disagrees’ with court on suspension of parliament
text:
British Prime Minister Boris Johnson speaks at United Nations (UN) Climate Action Summit on September 23, 2019 in New York City | Spencer Platt/Getty Images Boris Johnson ‘strongly disagrees’ with court on suspension of parliament Parliament will sit again from Wednesday at 11.30 am U.K. time

NEW YORK — Boris Johnson said he "strongly disagrees" with the U.K.'s highest court that he acted illegally when he suspended parliament but added he would accept the ruling.

Speaking in New York ahead of a business event, the prime minister said: “Obviously this is a verdict that we will respect and we respect the judicial process."

“I have to say that I strongly disagree with what the justices have found. I don’t think that it’s right but we will go ahead and of course parliament will come back.”

The ruling went much further than observers had expected and is a severe blow to Johnson and his team.

However, a No.10 spokesman said the prime minister would not resign, though added Johnson would fly back from the U.S. Tuesday night after addressing the United Nations General Assembly rather than Wednesday, as planned.

Johnson said parliament would have plenty of time to debate Brexit ahead of the U.K.'s scheduled exit from the European Union on October 31.

"Parliament has been debating Brexit for three years solidly. Now is the chance for us to get a deal, come out of the EU on October 31 and that is what we are going to do," the prime minister said.
description: Parliament will sit again from Wednesday at 11.30 am U.K. time
